questions.text: Which of the following is not a measure of position?
questions.solution:
Range is not a measure of position, it is a measure of dispersion or spread.

The most common measures of position are quantiles, quartiles, centiles and z-scores (standard scores). Measures of position give the position of specific data in relation to other data in the set.

Related Pearl: Measures in Statistics

Measures used in statistics

Definition

Examples

Measures of Location or Central Tendency

These measures summarize the data by defining the centre or the middle.

An entire distribution can be characterized by these measures which represent all the observations.

Mean, median, mode

Measures of Dispersion or Variability or Spread

These measures help in determining the extent to which data is stretched or squeezed.

Range, interquartile range, variance, standard deviation

Measures of Position

These measures give the position of specific data in relation to other data in the set.

Percentiles, quartiles, centiles,  z scores

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about quantiles are true?
  1. They divide data into equal groups
  2. They are used for discrete data
  3. Median is a type of quantile
  4. Quintiles divide the distribution into 4 equal parts
  5. They are also known as fractiles
questions.solution:
Quantiles are elements in a distribution that divide data into equal groups. They are also known as fractiles. Median divides a distribution into two equal parts, so it is considered as a quantile.Â 

Quantiles are used for continuous, quantitative data.

Quintiles are a type of quantile that divides data into 5 equal groups.

Related Pearl: Quantiles

Quantiles are elements in a distribution that divide it into equal groups.

  • They are also referred to as fractiles.
  • Quantiles are used for continuous, quantitative data.
  • The median is also considered a quantile as it divides a distribution into two equal parts. The median is also the same as the 50th percentile and second quartile.

Types of quantiles:

  1. Tertiles divide a distribution into 3 equal groups
  2. Quartiles divide it into 4 equal parts or quarters
  3. Quintiles divide a distribution into 5 equal groups
  4. Deciles divide a distribution into 10 equal parts
  5. Vigintiles divide it into 20 equal groups
  6. Centiles:
  • They are also called percentiles and are commonly used, especially for ranking marks in an exam.
  • They divide a distribution into 100 equal parts. Here, the median is the same as the 50th percentile.
  • The formula to arrive at the rank order of a value is R = P/100 x (n + 1), where R is the rank of the desired observation, P is the percentile desired and n is the number of variables in the data.

questions.text: Centiles divide data into ____ equal parts?
questions.solution:
Centiles divide data into 100 equal parts.

Related Pearl: Quantiles

Quantiles are elements in a distribution that divide it into equal groups.

  • They are also referred to as fractiles.
  • Quantiles are used for continuous, quantitative data.
  • The median is also considered a quantile as it divides a distribution into two equal parts. The median is also the same as the 50th percentile and second quartile.

  2. Quartiles divide it into 4 equal parts or quarters
  3. Quintiles divide a distribution into 5 equal groups
  4. Deciles divide a distribution into 10 equal parts

  • They divide a distribution into 100 equal parts. Here, the median is the same as the 50th percentile.
  • The formula to arrive at the rank order of a value is R = P/100 x (n + 1), where R is the rank of the desired observation, P is the percentile desired and n is the number of variables in the data.

questions.text: During a school health camp, a group of 250 students are arranged in the ascending order of their height. Which student would have the 40th percentile value for height?
questions.solution:
Here, the 100th student will have the 40th percentile value for height.

To arrive at this, we use the formula R = P/100 x (n + 1).
where R is the rank of the desired observation, P is the quantile/percentile desired and n is the number of variables in the data.

Thus, R = 40/100 x (250 + 1) = 0.4 x 251 = 100.4.

This is rounded up to the closest number making R = 100.

questions.text: By calculating which of the following can we obtain the central value of a sample with 180 elements?
questions.solution:
The 2nd quartile gives the central value of 180 elements. The central value of a distribution is given by the median. It divides the distribution into the ratio of 1:1.

In quartiles elements of the distribution are divided into 4 equal parts by 3 values. Each part contains a quarter, i.e., 25% of the values. So two quarters would give half of the values. So the element present at the position of the 2nd quartile would be the central value, i.e., the median, with half the values before and half the values after it. This is shown in the image given below.

The 5th decile and 50th percentile represent the median values of a distribution in decile and percentile respectively.

questions.text: Which measure of position divides the distribution in a ratio of 3:1?
questions.solution:
Third quartile Q3 divides the distribution into the ratio of 3:1. 

In quartiles:

  • the first quartile Q1 divides the distribution in the ratio of 1:3
  • the second quartile Q2 divides it in the ratio of 1:1.

The division of data by quartiles is shown in the below image.

Centiles divide data into 100 equal parts. 33rd centile divides the distribution in the ratio of 33:67.

Deciles divide data into 10 equal parts. 7th decile divides the distribution in the ratio of 7:3.

Related Pearl: Quantiles

questions.text: You are recording the blood pressure values of 200 adults in a population. The first quartile diastolic BP is 68 mmHg and the third quartile is 105 mmHg. How many patients are there in the 3rd and 4th quarters?
questions.solution:
In a quartile, the data is divided into 4 equal parts, i.e., 4 quarters. Therefore, in this scenario, there are 50% of patients in the 3rd and 4th quarters, i.e 100 patients.

The division of data by quartiles is shown in the image given below.

Related Pearl: Quantiles

questions.text: The forced expiratory volume (FEV) of 300 patients visiting the respiratory medicine outpatient department is recorded. The data has a median value of 2.5 litres with the first and third quartiles being 1.5 litres and 4.5 litres respectively. How many persons in the sample are expected to have an FEV between 1.5 and 4.5 litres?
questions.solution:
150 persons are expected to have FEV between 1.5 and 4.5 litres.

In a quartile, the data is divided by 3 values into 4 equal parts. Thus, each part will have 25% of the values in the distribution.

In this scenario, each part will have 75 persons. Here, 1.5 is the first quartile Q1, 2.5 is the second quartile Q2 and 4.5 is the third quartile Q3. Between Q1 and Q3 there are two quarters, thus there will be 150 people with FEV between 1.5 and 4.5 litres.

Data division by quartiles is shown in the below image.

Related Pearl: Quantiles

Quantiles are elements in a distribution that divide it into equal groups.

  • They are also referred to as fractiles.
  • Quantiles are used for continuous, quantitative data.
  • The median is also considered a quantile as it divides a distribution into two equal parts. The median is also the same as the 50th percentile and second quartile.

Types of quantiles:

questions.text: Which of the following distributions is preferred for the calculation of z scores?
questions.solution:
Z scores are usually calculated in normal distributions.

Related Pearl: Z Scores

  • Z score indicates the position of any element in a distribution in terms of how many standard deviations it lies from the mean of the distribution.
  • It is also called the standard score.
  • If it lies above the mean, its z score will be positive and if it lies below it, the z score will be negative.
  • For example, if an element lies 1.5 standard deviations below the mean, its z score will be -1.5 and if it lies 0.5 standard deviations above the mean, its z score will be +0.5.
  • The formula for calculating z scores is z = (X- µ)/σ, where x is the element’s value, µ is the mean and σ is the standard deviation. From this, we can also calculate the actual value of the element.
  • Some of the z-values for commonly used percentiles:

 

Percentile

Z value

1st

-2.326

2.5th

-1.960

5th

-1.645

10th

-1.282

25th

-0.675

50th

0

75th

0.675

90th

1.282

95th

1.645

97.5th

1.960

99th

2.326

questions.text: In a study on haemoglobin levels in healthy women, the data recorded has a mean of 13.5 gm/dL and a standard deviation of 1.5 gm/dL. What is the z score for an element with a haemoglobin value of 15.0 gm/dL?
questions.solution:
The Z score for the element with a haemoglobin value of 15 gm/dL is 1.0.

The formula for z score, z = (X- µ)/σ.

X is the value of the element, µ is the mean and σ is the standard deviation.

In this scenario, z = (15 – 13.5) / 1.5 = 1.5/1.5 = 1.

Related Pearl: Z Scores

  • Z score indicates the position of any element in a distribution in terms of how many standard deviations it lies from the mean of the distribution.
  • It is also called the standard score.
  • If it lies above the mean, its z score will be positive and if it lies below it, the z score will be negative.
  • For example, if an element lies 1.5 standard deviations below the mean, its z score will be -1.5 and if it lies 0.5 standard deviations above the mean, its z score will be +0.5.
  • The formula for calculating z scores is z = (X- µ)/σ, where x is the element’s value, µ is the mean and σ is the standard deviation. From this, we can also calculate the actual value of the element.
  • Some of the z-values for commonly used percentiles:

questions.text: The diastolic BP of 125 women aged between 18 and 60 years was recorded. The mean of the data is 70 mmHg with a standard deviation of 10 mmHg. What will be the 5th percentile value?
questions.solution:
The z value for the 5th percentile is -1.645.

Using the formula for z scores, z = (X- µ)/σ, we get X = zσ + µ.

In this scenario, X = (-1.645 x 10) + 70 = -16.45 + 70 = 53.55 = 53.6.
